results.title: Managing aggressive behaviour
results.creator_credit: Tim Abbott, Helen Edwards, Tony Shaddock and New England Educational Diagnostic Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Managing difficult behaviours”.
Module 3.1. Designed to assist the intellectual disability residential care worker to understand why aggressive behaviour occurs, learn how to “get in first” to avoid aggressive outbursts and how to deal systematically with particular forms of aggressive behaviour that have become a regular behaviour pattern. Accompanied by 48p. in-service training manual.

results.title: Frontline. Series 2. One big family. Working class man. Divide the community, multiply the ratings. Changing the face of current affairs.
results.creator_credit: Jane Kennedy, Rob Sitch, Santo Cilauro, Tom Gleisner, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Frontline TV Prod
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontline”.
In “One big family” ratings are down but the new network promo takes first priority. Mike attempts to broaden his image by becoming a “Working class man.” The Frontline team are investigating ethnic violence in “Divide the community, multiply the ratings”. A consultant is called in to help ratings in “Changing the face of current affairs.”

results.title: Frontline. Series 1. Playing the ego card. Add sex and stir. Smaller fish to fry. This night of nights
results.creator_credit: Jane Kennedy, Rob Sitch, Santo Cilauro, Tom Gleisner, ABC and Frontline TV Prod
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontline”.
Four episodes from the highly acclaimed television series. In “Playing the ego card” Mike wants to boost his credibility and Brook wants the front desk. In “Add sex and stir” Mike has a busy time organising a party and the Frontline team stir up a hot story about lesbianism in sport. Will Mike stick to his guns in “Smaller fish to fry” when he investigates some top businessmen. “This night of nights” takes a look at the Logies.

results.title: Frontline. Series 1. Desert angel. The Siege. We ain't got dames.
results.creator_credit: Jane Kennedy, Rob Sitch, Santo Cilauro, Tom Gleisner, ABC-TV (Australia) and Frontline Television Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontline”.
Three episodes from the highly acclaimed Australian comedy show which exposes life behind the cameras of a popular current affairs program. A beautiful aid worker believed missing in the desert is found and the Frontline staff attempt to get an exclusive in “Desert angel.” Meanwhile, another network tries to poach legendary anchorman Mike Moore. A gunman takes several hostages in a remote farmhouse, and Frontline’s questionable methods to gain a scoop boosts their ratings in “The Siege.” Frontline tries to woo back female viewers by ditching their Friday night funnyman in “We ain’t got dames.”
results.title_for_label: Frontline. Series 1. Desert angel. The Siege. We ain’t got dames.

group_works.title: The Cause of liberty
group_works.creator_credit: William Francisco, Robert Saudek, Learning Corporation of America and Robert Saudek Associates

results.title: The Cause of liberty
results.creator_credit: William Francisco, Robert Saudek, Learning Corporation of America and Robert Saudek Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American revolution”.
This dramatisation stars a youthful Michael Douglas and James Woods and is based on the letters of John and Henry Laurens, written between 1772-1776. The letters between father and son give a first-hand account of some of the events and issues surrounding the American Revolution. An interesting comparison is made between the call for national independence by America and the prohibition of slavery in England.

results.title: The Hand of Stalin
results.creator_credit: John Walker, Tom Roberts, British Broadcasting Corporation and October Films
results.brief_description: A three part series examining the history of Stalinism in the former Soviet UnioN focusing on oral histories of people who lived through the turbulent and totalitarian Communist regime of the late 1930s. As they relive memories of collectivisation, the purges and the Gulags, the series becomes an almost unbearable testament to the brutality of power. However, by talking to peasants, intellectuals, former KGB and dissenters, the series avoids histrionics and controversy and allows the dignity of people’s voices to tell their own stories.

results.title: Kolyma
results.creator_credit: Murray Battle, Angus MacQueen, Tom Roberts, BBC and October Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Hand of Stalin”.
Kolyma is in North-East Russia, on the wild Pacific Coast and under Stalin’s reign it was a Gulag prison camp. The Gulags were a network of forced labour-camps throughout the Soviet Union and literally tens of millions of Soviet citizens were imprisoned in the camps during the 1930s and 1940s. Kolyma is a gold mine territory and the prisoners were forced to work the mines, clear the forests while enduring horrific climatic conditions in the freezing Siberian terrain. Interviews with ex-prisoners who served sentences ranging from ten to twenty-five years, detail the miserable conditions in which they lived and worked, while interviews with the camp administrators make it clear that throughout the prison system it was wide-spread knowledge that the majority of prisoners where innocent of their crimes. This final episode of “The Hand of Stalin” documents with ferocious passion, the damage done by a totalitarian ruler in his thirst for personal power and by his blind adherance to the dogmas of a Communist faith.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Murray Battle, Angus MacQueen, Tom Roberts, BBC and October Films

results.title: Leningrad
results.creator_credit: John Walker, Angus MacQueen, Tom Roberts, BBC and October Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Hand of Stalin”.
In the 1930s Stalin consolidated his power by creating a strict heirarchical level of command which depended upon paranoia and authoritarian repression for success. Millions of people were accused of “crimes against the state” and forced to sign confessions in show trials which only added to the growing societal hysteria. In interviews with both survivors and administrators of the “purges”, we see how the use of informers and the secret police led to a social order of mistrust where neigbour turned on neighbour and sibling on sibling. Filmed in the old city of Leningrad this powerful documentary shows how the purges, with their subsequant tortures, imprisonments and violence are still the cause of deep anguish for contemporary Russians.
